comments.commentBody: Revenge is not the answer. But any American circa 2015 should know better, in both heart and mind, than to falsely morally equate military operations, which always have military objectives but do virtually always result in civilian casualties, and terrorism, which is the use of violence or threat of violence against civilians to instill fear so as to try to effect one's agenda, be it political, religious, economic, or what-not.  (The torture killing of the Jordanian pilot, while not, strictly speaking, terrorism, since he was not a civilian, so purposely and intensively violates the rules of warfare that it is in essence if not letter also terrorism.)
This stance says there is no such thing as a legitimate war.  It is true that there is no moral war.  But we owe our existence to legitmate ones.

I condemn all violence -- while acknowledging that everyone, including me, has a darkness, a shadow, that can in the "right" circumstances produce the most terrible evil. Burning people alive is wrong, whether the burning is done by ISIS or by American pilots (bombs cause fires, you know); calls for crucifixion are wrong, whether the calls are made by a Roman officer two thousand years ago or an Islamic leader today; killing people is wrong, period.  Revenge is not the answer.

Add the Soviet Union, who really turned the war around with the defeat of Von Paulus' Army at Stalingrad.  In all, they lost 20 million Soviet lives resisting the Germans.  There is every possibility that Hitler would have controlled all of Europe including Britain without the Soviet Front to chew him up.

Don't be deluded. Big bucks citizens and residents of the U.S. do not pay taxes on earnings outside the U.S. That is what they may report on their tax forms, but 'taint true. Much of that income goes into corporations in tax havens that are forbidden by local laws to divulge the names of their stockholders. The only answer, which those involved in such schemes will demand that their congress members block, is to play hardball with the tax haven countries. Ban transactions between their banks and U.S. banks until they lift this veil of secrecy. To make that effective we need Western Europe, Canada, Australia and Japan to join us in a joint "get tough"policy. One fears that too many politicos (here and elsewhere) are party to these tax avoidance schemes for the problem to be dragged out into the sunlight.

How can President Obama justify a transition tax corporate rate of only 14% (CTJ estimates $82 billion gift to just 10 of the worst offshore tax dodgers) that becomes only a 19% maximum corporate tax rate?

Why assume like Josh Barrow that a corporate tax rate still incentivizing corporations to move jobs off shore and to race-to-the-bottom tax rate countries might not do much harm? This is tax rates, not rocket science.

Incentives are often 'donated' to buy representatives from both parties, to call support for legislative proposals bipartisan, so Josh Barro claim that territorial taxation is best for our economy because it is bipartisan only insults voters.

Anyone not being paid to agree would instead rather know how well someone's proposal (especially anyone who received corporate campaign or think tank funding) for corporate taxation taxes "the fraction of the company’s sales, employees, and capital that occurs within any given jurisdiction," like our tried and tested U.S. states taxation system.

Joseph Stiglitz explained, almost a year ago in plain English, what we need for, "Ensuring that Multinationals Pay Their Fair Share of Taxes and Have Incentives to Invest in America". News media and legislative proposers should explain to voters how their proposals compare. Read pages 15 and 16 of Stiglitz's white paper at the Roosevelt Institute:
http://rooseveltinstitute.org/sites/all/files/Stiglitz_Reforming_Taxatio...

Moralizing necessitates simplification, and, we suppose, has value, so 24b4Jeff can be excused his facile point; but i would like to tell him that we are all better off living in a society guilty of conducting drone strikes than in a society guilty of burning people in cages. If he is not sure why this is so, he should consider life for common people in Europe's 17th century, or look at pictures of towns run by ISIS with rows of heads on poles.

This is just dumb and not helpful. Blanket statements that stir the pot about somebody's religion that you probably don't know anything about as "the largest killer of Syrians" means what exactly?  Ugh.

My point was more, why give benefits to manufacturers? Obama needs to get over his romanticizing of manufacturing (and farming too while we're at it).

You could have say, an airline, not a manufacturer, but employs a lot of people and provides a much needed service...they'll get taxed at 28% vs. an automated car manufacturing facility that may only employ a few people gets taxed at 28%.

The logic of trying to bucket corporations, tasks and people is just silly. It's creates divisiveness. Especially when arbitrarily made up by some politician in Washington. Just look at how trying to label people as middle-class vs rich has turned out...

That clip is priceless! Thanks for sharing, Liz.

Steve Allen was notorious for his contempt of rock & roll during the early days.
You win the prize for Best Memory today Liz.
Thanks, Deadline!  I'll treasure my trophy!

Awesome construction and a smooth straightforward solve. Is today really Thursday. Unlike Deb, I am old enough to remember THE LEADER OF THE PACK. The Shangri-Las were considered a rather campy ripoff of the more popular girl groups, like the Shirelles. I had a friend in college who was though of as cool untill we found "The Best of the Shangi-Las" in his album collection.

Conversational echo style was parodied beautifull in "The Leader of the Laundromat," by the Detergents.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qi5yDBvYUcE

MJ
If

"What is under discussion is the de-contextualized view of philosophy, the sort of Anglo-American analytic philosophy, which (to me) are more mind-games than anything else."

Here is a thought, say so.

One consequence, carve out dead white male continental philosophy from the blather. Terminates most of the uhh, "critique." This is old news that fails to even clash with the Anglo American analytic tradition.
Likewise there are mass killings conducted by boko harum in Aftrica but the outrage is low.

It is perhaps better late than never but if the same outrage was expressed when the first western hostages were beheaded we would have been looking at a different geopolitical landscape - it took the killing of a muslim for the muslim outrage to finally flow over. So be it.

American movies and television thrive on gun violence, as movie producers have come to understand that blazing guns sell movie tickets. One episode of Jennifer Garner's "Alias" series, for example, features a dozen violent incidents involving a high body count. Pick any other action/suspense film or TV series for an equal exposure to violence, guns, and shootings.

American society suffers tens of thousands of incidents of gun violence every year involving shootings, murders, accidents, suicides, and other mayhem. Do movies influence perceptions and behavior regarding guns and violence? Every gun owner in America has at one point had a personal fantasy, emulating Clint Eastwood's character Harry Callahan. "Go ahead, punk. Make my day!"

"Movies often still have the power to provoke national debate." Or perhaps gun violence as well...

Common! Your point about the movie, Wall Street, is well taken, and makes sense! I even worked in that industry for nineteen years, before having a sort of epiphany (though some of my female acquaintances thought I was nuts!) and becoming a certified Social Studies teacher, about twenty years ago...However, I think the sea change occurred starting with that show, The Lifestyles of The Rich and Famous, followed by that movie where the character, Tom Cruise is playing, says, SHOW ME THE MONEY!!!

The thesis of this article is that popular cinema can change individual attitudes; nothing really surprising there, and frankly I think the Times' readers didn't need a study to illustrate the point.

But the better these is that popular cinema can change the nation's zeitgeist. For proof of this I would point to Wall Street, and the moral shift that this Nation began upon its release. In the ensuing years Gordon Gecko's "Greed is Good" philosophy has become acceptable, so much so that a VERY sizable percentage of mainstream politicians -- and their constituents -- have no problem with selfishness, even to the point of publicly accepting Ayn Rand, whose philosophy was totally discredited in the 80's when Wall Street was released.

Take a look David at this http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/08/west-training-syrian-rebels...
or put these some words into a search engine "training camps jordan syria"

Sure, Jordan has been working with the US. It was the US training the terrorists/rebels in Jordan, under exotic names like FSA (Free Syrian army)
They are waiting until a search and rescue infrastructure is put into place.   I would have done the same thing.
If a Westerner were to meted such treatment, reaction would have been much muted.
I like Oleg/Costa Ronin. Can someone please tell Oleg that American burgers can kill you? Oleg: Stick with Chicken Kiev and borscht!

Zinaida's likely got a poisoned Zagnut in her future, but might stick around long enough to serve up a few more ironic digs at the USA a la the "trying to determine the future of other countries" line she delivers at the presser...and continuing the junk food theme, nothing hits the spot after a post-coital throttling like a nice cold brewski. I've still got to believe Stan's going to have a Hank Shrader a-ha moment (in a season or two) regarding the Jennings, but perhaps he can do his gastronomic part and shortly deliver Oleg a hamburger. Nina's likely headed for a stainless steel room and her cellmate seems like some sort of plant to determine her true feelings, but was she truthful re not pretending with Oleg, or just playing his dad? Is Paige ready to become a spy for Mother Russia? Well, if that newspaper she was reading was the New York Times....

While it might be relatively easy to "attribute" these newly discovered sculptures to Michelangelo, it's really just an attribution the work to his era, rather than by his own hand. But somehow I doubt if it's really from the master's own hands, and I doubt it too if this could ever be confirmed beyond any doubt.
Is it just me, or did anyone else sense some sort of drinking game pegged to the frequency with which characters said "sh*t" during this episode?

Philosophers embrace that race is a social construct. They also recognize that its social construction makes its impact on human lives no less real. It is that very real impact that is the target of philosophical investigations of race. The aim of that discipline is to analyze the patterns and logic underlying race relations, in order to find ways to challenge and revise those patterns.

By abstaining from discussions about race, academic disciplines allow the perpetuation of the sort of racial stereotypy and essentialism you allude to. Discussing racism is not equivalent to endorsing it. One must understand a phenomenon in order to effectively dismantle it.

I wholeheartedly disagree that philosophy should focus exclusively on "pure analytical cognitive discourse". Doing so has only fostered a demographic crisis in academic philosophy, which excludes nearly all but white male voices from its conversations.

In response to Joseph, the few Americans that were in Syria and died in the hands of ISIS, were there on their own free will. They were not American soldiers on a mission led by the U.S. government. As such, President Obama bears no responsibility for their death.
I think you must have missed the appearance on the human stage of Hitler and Stalin, both atheists, who committed atrocities far outstripping any modern terrorists of whatever religion.
Speaking of barrel bombs, what is approbation? Tell us so we can answer your question.

It's good that the Arab world has finally united against ISIS and that Sheikh Tayeb proposed a punishment that is as much of an eye for an eye as Islam allows, but where has the Arab world been up to this point?

The principle of taking somebody's life because you feel like it and the inhumanity and brutality of a 'simple' beheading or of suicide bombings doesn't bother them. They only object to this latest killing because ISIS burned a man alive and that man is an Arab, not a westerner, and Islam prohibits death by fire as too extreme of a measure. Well, being beheaded is an extreme measure to the victim and to his family.

And where is the approbation for Assad dropping barrel bombs – barrels filled with shrapnel dropped miscellaneously? Islam allows that? I’m grateful that the Muslim world is speaking out but what happens when the next beheading occurs?

"The Arab world by denying that it's people are divinely created equal with certain unalienable rights including life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness is recruiting for ISIL, al Qaeda in Yemen, Saudi Arabia, Iraq."

You can't be serious. There are significant religious and cultural differences between Secular American society and Muslim Arab society. Only those that don't understand these differences lead and support the American invasion of Iraq under a nation-building disguise.

you missed what the article meant, unfortunately. this is the issue with corporate taxes, it's complicated.

If Apple sells its iPhones in the US but allocates all profits to China, that is fine (but hard, because they don't own the manifacturing, but let's ignore that and take a company that does). That company would then owe China taxes on all that profit. And finally, what is being proposed, is if that tax rate is below 19%, you have to make up the difference to the US government that year.

This is a huge win for people who want fairer corporate taxes. No matter what, you owe at least 19% of your profits to SOMEONE. If that person is the netherlands, fine. If that person is the US government, fine. But you can't just use the double irish with a dutch sandwich to lower taxes to 0 in the EU and then just keep reinvesting that money in Europe (which unlike Bermuda, has real economic possibilities for your money) and not paying a share.

Better still would be a flat tax rate for it all, rather than a reduced foreign rate vs domestic rate. Dial it in at 23 or 22% and that is it. But I'll take this as step one.

you owe at least 19% of your profits
There won't ever BE any profits. They will see to that. Since the cost of manufacturing is a deduction, you will see costs skyrocket.
Just like when we get that dazzling social security increase of 1.7%, everything else including rent goes up 5%. because they paid an extra buck for lawn service.

The article overlooks the assumes that the allocation of profits to overseas actually represents the earnings in the overseas rather than the wholly arbitrary allocation of costs to foreign countries that are complete smoke.

No doubt if Apple says its' iPhones selling for $600 retail have marketing
and distribution costs of $15 in the U.S. and pays its' Chinese subsidiary $585 for design, manufacturing, and shipping to the U.S.; its' U.S. profit is zero. GE has done the same thing for years, resulting in record profits little or no U.S. federal taxes, and sometimes tax refunds; all while profits pile up offshore.

Of course, both companies expect to the full force of U.S. diplomatic and military resources to protect their intellectual property and trade routes.
What about letting loose and having fun, diarubo? All it takes is some irrationality!
